summary: This is a formal letter from the French Ministry of Justice's International Criminal Assistance Bureau to the U.S. Department of Justice, transmitted via the U.S. Embassy in Paris. It explains French legal provisions regarding extradition, specifically stating that French nationality at the time of an alleged offense constitutes an absolute bar to extradition, and that subsequent loss of nationality does not change this.

persons.name: Andrew Finkelman
persons.context: Serves as the liaison magistrate on behalf of the U.S. Embassy in Paris, France, through whom the French Ministry of Justice is transmitting this correspondence to the U.S. Department of Justice.

persons.name: Philipp E Cift
persons.role: Head of the International Criminal Assistance Bureau
persons.context: Appears to be the signatory or head of the French bureau authoring this official legal correspondence regarding extradition law.

locations: Embassy of the United States of America, Paris
keyFacts: French law (Article 694-4 of the Code of Criminal Procedure) absolutely prohibits the extradition of French nationals, assessed at the time the alleged offense was committed.
The loss of French nationality after the commission of an offense does not remove this legal barrier to extradition.
The document is a formal communication from the French Ministry of Justice to the U.S. Department of Justice, dated March 9, 2021.
The letter clarifies the legal framework (Articles 696 et seq.) governing extradition proceedings in France.
The correspondence is transmitted through Andrew Finkelman, the U.S. Liaison Magistrate at the embassy in Paris.
